channel.title: 317 Server->Client In-Use Opcode List
channel.description:
This is really simple, but handy for people who just want to know without doing 5 minutes of parsing.
These are the opcodes that are used for for server to client communication in the 317 client: [code] //FORMAT: //opcode # exists opcode -1 true opcode 0 false opcode 1 true opcode 2 false opcode 3 false opcode 4 true opcode 5 false opcode 6 false opcode 7 false opcode 8 true opcode 9 false opcode 10 false opcode 11 false opcode 12 false opcode 13 false opcode 14 false opcode 15 false opcode 16 false opcode 17 false opcode 18 false opcode 19 false opcode 20 false opcode 21 false opcode 22 false opcode 23 false opcode 24 true opcode 25 false opcode 26 false opcode 27 true opcode 28 false opcode 29 false opcode 30 false opcode 31 false opcode 32 false opcode 33 false opcode 34 true opcode 35 true opcode 36 true opcode 37 false opcode 38 false opcode 39 false opcode 40 false opcode 41 false opcode 42 false opcode 43 false opcode 44 true opcode 45 false opcode 46 false opcode 47 false opcode 48 false opcode 49 false opcode 50 true opcode 51 false opcode 52 false opcode 53 true opcode 54 false opcode 55 false opcode 56 false opcode 57 false opcode 58 false opcode 59 false opcode 60 true opcode 61 true opcode 62 false opcode 63 false opcode 64 true opcode 65 true opcode 66 false opcode 67 false opcode 68 true opcode 69 false opcode 70 true opcode 71 true opcode 72 true opcode 73 true opcode 74 true opcode 75 true opcode 76 false opcode 77 false opcode 78 true opcode 79 true opcode 80 false opcode 81 true opcode 82 false opcode 83 false opcode 84 true opcode 85 true opcode 86 false opcode 87 true opcode 88 false opcode 89 false opcode 90 false opcode 91 false opcode 92 false opcode 93 false opcode 94 false opcode 95 false opcode 96 false opcode 97 true opcode 98 false opcode 99 true opcode 100 false opcode 101 true opcode 102 false opcode 103 false opcode 104 true opcode 105 true opcode 106 true opcode 107 true opcode 108 false opcode 109 true opcode 110 true opcode 111 false opcode 112 false opcode 113 false opcode 114 true opcode 115 false opcode 116 false opcode 117 true opcode 118 false opcode 119 false opcode 120 false opcode 121 true opcode 122 true opcode 123 false opcode 124 false opcode 125 false opcode 126 true opcode 127 false opcode 128 false opcode 129 false opcode 130 false opcode 131 false opcode 132 false opcode 133 false opcode 134 true opcode 135 false opcode 136 false opcode 137 false opcode 138 false opcode 139 false opcode 140 false opcode 141 false opcode 142 true opcode 143 false opcode 144 false opcode 145 false opcode 146 false opcode 147 true opcode 148 false opcode 149 false opcode 150 false opcode 151 true opcode 152 false opcode 153 false opcode 154 false opcode 155 false opcode 156 true opcode 157 false opcode 158 false opcode 159 false opcode 160 true opcode 161 false opcode 162 false opcode 163 false false opcode 200 true opcode 201 false opcode 202 false opcode 203 false opcode 204 false opcode 205 false opcode 206 true opcode 207 false opcode 208 true opcode 209 false opcode 210 false opcode 211 false opcode 212 false opcode 213 false opcode 214 true opcode 215 true opcode 216 false opcode 217 false opcode 218 true opcode 219 true opcode 220 false opcode 221 true opcode 222 false opcode 223 false opcode 224 false opcode 225 false opcode 226 false opcode 227 false opcode 228 false opcode 229 false opcode 230 true opcode 231 false opcode 232 false opcode 233 false opcode 234 false opcode 235 false opcode 236 false opcode 237 false opcode 238 false opcode 239 false opcode 240 true opcode 241 true opcode 242 false opcode 243 false opcode 244 false opcode 245 false opcode 246 true opcode 247 false opcode 248 true opcode 249 true opcode 250 false opcode 251 false opcode 252 false opcode 253 true opcode 254 true [/code] Out of 255 opcodes, 74 are in use.
What are the uses for this? * Implementing custom packets * Knowing what opcodes to document

item.title: 317 Server->Client In-Use Opcode List
item.dc:creator: @imsuperman05 imsuperman05
item.description:
@imsuperman05 wrote:

This is useful, I will prob use some of these.

On the other hand: Somebody should go and document most of the client>server packets in rswiki, i need to learn most of the protocol (such as walking).

Read full topic

item.title: 317 Server->Client In-Use Opcode List

item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Why not just add an ‘unused’ section to

http://rswiki.moparisthebest.com/index.php?title=317_Protocol

?

Or, in http://rswiki.moparisthebest.com/index.php?title=317_Protocol#Game_Protocol
Add all of them with a type ‘unused’

Read full topic

item.title: 317 Server->Client In-Use Opcode List
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:8, topic:433963”][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=536682.msg3924385#msg3924385 date=1330055811]

Cool?

Are you stupid or just trying to be cool because you’ve got that badge?

Well I was first like, hmm, because the wiki has a list like this. Well not exactly but you could piece together something like this with the information from the list. I’m more interested in your technique to get this information. I don’t see how it could be a critically important list unless you had the sizes for each packet. I wasn’t trying to offend.
[/quote]
a) the wiki is missing some packets (documented or not)
b) the technique was literally copy and pasting the packet parsing block and using regex to filter the opcodes used in the conditionals.
c) the packet sizes can easily be obtained by looking them up in the table with in the client via opcode (since you know which opcodes are in use, you can look up the length). obviously, various opcodes have a variable length (indicated by -1 (iirc) in the table).
d) critically important, no. possible uses, yes (see OP).[/quote]

If you have the list of missing (use your regecks skills to find it ) I will be willing to write the documention for the ones missing.

Read full topic

item.title: 317 Server->Client In-Use Opcode List
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:8, topic:433963”][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=536682.msg3924385#msg3924385 date=1330055811]

Cool?

Are you stupid or just trying to be cool because you’ve got that badge?

Well I was first like, hmm, because the wiki has a list like this. Well not exactly but you could piece together something like this with the information from the list. I’m more interested in your technique to get this information. I don’t see how it could be a critically important list unless you had the sizes for each packet. I wasn’t trying to offend.
[/quote]
a) the wiki is missing some packets (documented or not)
b) the technique was literally copy and pasting the packet parsing block and using regex to filter the opcodes used in the conditionals.
c) the packet sizes can easily be obtained by looking them up in the table with in the client via opcode (since you know which opcodes are in use, you can look up the length). obviously, various opcodes have a variable length (indicated by -1 (iirc) in the table).
d) critically important, no. possible uses, yes (see OP).[/quote]

Ah okay, regex.

Read full topic

item.title: 317 Server->Client In-Use Opcode List
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:7, topic:433963”][quote author=t4 link=topic=536682.msg3924378#msg3924378 date=1330055307]

Cool?

Are you stupid or just trying to be cool because you’ve got that badge?
[/quote]

Well I was first like, hmm, because the wiki has a list like this. Well not exactly but you could piece together something like this with the information from the list. I’m more interested in your technique to get this information. I don’t see how it could be a critically important list unless you had the sizes for each packet. I wasn’t trying to offend.[/quote]
a) the wiki is missing some packets (documented or not)
b) the technique was literally copy and pasting the packet parsing block and using regex to filter the opcodes used in the conditionals.
c) the packet sizes can easily be obtained by looking them up in the table with in the client via opcode (since you know which opcodes are in use, you can look up the length). obviously, various opcodes have a variable length (indicated by -1 (iirc) in the table).
d) critically important, no. possible uses, yes (see OP).

Read full topic

item.title: 317 Server->Client In-Use Opcode List
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:6, topic:433963”][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=536682.msg3924373#msg3924373 date=1330054430]
Cool?
[/quote]
Are you stupid or just trying to be cool because you’ve got that badge?[/quote]

Well I was first like, hmm, because the wiki has a list like this. Well not exactly but you could piece together something like this with the information from the list. I’m more interested in your technique to get this information. I don’t see how it could be a critically important list unless you had the sizes for each packet. I wasn’t trying to offend.

Read full topic

item.title: 317 Server->Client In-Use Opcode List
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

Native^:

No payload-buffer data information? Thanks for the share anyway.

Wasn’t the point of the post.

Miss Silabsoft:

http://rswiki.moparisthebest.com/index.php?title=317_Protocol <- pretty sure most if not all are here if you see any that actually missing let me know and I can post it.

I was the one who put the wiki up. The ones that are missing would be the ones in the above post marked as true and don’t appear in the wiki.

Read full topic
